description.S1: Conrad is one of the four people Silas sent you to collect from.
description.S2: He runs a barber shop in Edgewater.

blurb.B1: Conrad Sadik is located in the Barber Shop inside Edgewater.
blurb.B2: You can talk to him and find out he is quite happy with his position at Edgewater,
blurb.B3: but he is broke and cannot afford the gravesite fee.
blurb.B4: He will offer his apologies and acceptance to have his Medical Rights revoked as he will have to default on this payment.
blurb.B5: He reveals he had the plague and was deemed worthy of treatment,
blurb.B6: but since the barber shop is not profitable he has spent his savings to keep it afloat.
blurb.B7: Tell him to give Silas an "I owe you".
blurb.B8: He will need something to give as collateral.
blurb.B9: Go to the back room and inspect a ledger and you'll find a note from Phyllis mentioning a receptionist's suicide and asking Conrad to pull the teeth.
blurb.B10: You can find the Golden Teeth items at the Botanical Labs greenhouse and bring them back,
blurb.B11: then use Persuade (1) and tell him that you have them.
blurb.B12: You will then receive 360xp and complete this portion of the quest.
blurb.B13: Alternatively: You can kill him for his Gravesite Fee

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Please don't touch anything. Your hands are probably crawling with germs.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Physical hygiene recapitulates moral hygiene. Cleanliness... is next to lawfulness.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Relax. I'm clean.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Do your haircuts usually come with free lectures?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I can show you my hands.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: So everyone says. Until someone forgets to cough into their elbow, and then we're all dying of plague.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I'm Conrad. You will report to me if your hair fails to meet Spacer's Choice aesthetic standards.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: You will also report to me in the event of your death, whereupon I will clean and prepare your remains for interment.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Silas sent me to collect your dues.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Prepare my remains for what?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Goodbye.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Ah. Gravesite fees. Silas and I have talked about this at length. I thought I'd made it clear my pecuniary situation precludes the necessary restitutions.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I don't understand a word you said.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I mean that I can't possibly pay my gravesite fees.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I simply cannot afford it. I am a blemish on the prosperity of our fair settlement. When I expire, I expect Silas to toss my body into a ditch.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I don't care. Pay up.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: You have a very loose definition of the word prosperity.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: That's some quality drama, Conrad. You should audition.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Don't be so hard on yourself.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: With what? My own blood?

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Tell Silas I can't afford to pay, and that I fully expect to have my medical rights revoked for this dereliction. With my apologies.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Hang on. Medical rights?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Just give Silas an IOU.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Some time ago, I fell ill with the plague. By the grace of the Law, and through my own hard work, I'd proven worthy of treatment.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Frankly, I don't imagine I'll earn that right a second time. The barber work hasn't been profitable, you see. I've had to keep this old place running with my own savings.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I don't have time for this.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Not a bad idea. But I'd need some kind of collateral. My pair of lucky clippers? No, that won't do.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Your idea intrigues me, but I'm afraid I don't have anything to give Silas. I'm open to suggestions.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I'll let you know if I think of anything.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Much obliged.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Edgewater is built on the discipline and sacrifice of its people. Say what you will about our town, but we all pull together.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Thank you, no. I despise the serials.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I have to be, if only to prepare myself for my inevitable dressing-down at the hands of corporate.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Burial, in the unfortunate event of a fatality. It's what a barber does. We make you presentable.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: I've got some questions for you.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Go ahead.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: You seem pretty enthusiastic about this place.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: What do you know about this plague?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Never mind. Goodbye.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Edgewater has been good to me. I consider myself privileged to work here.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I am never wanting for work, not since the plagues started.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Sounds exhausting.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: That's all for now.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: As the good vicar says, work fortifies the spirit of a man. If you want to feel exhausted, try not having any work.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: The plague's come at us with a vengeance this year. Lost six workers in as many months.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: I wouldn't call them good workers, mind you. If they were any good, they'd have been treated. Still, it is a shame.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: What are the symptoms?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Why don't you treat all your workers?

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Fever. Chills. Fatigue. Aching. Vomiting. An excess of phlegm. A tendency toward bellyaching.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: What you're describing sounds a lot like a flu.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Whatever it may be, I have developed my own palliative. Boiled canid liver and a splash of ethanol.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Company policy, friend. We don't have enough medicine to treat all of us, so we treat the best among us.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Sensible policy.

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: Whose idea was that?

dialog.speaker: Player
dialog.utterance: That's monstrous.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: We're a sensible people.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Mr. Tobson's brainchild. Have you met him yet? Thoughtful-looking fellow. Stares out of his office most hours.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: Nature is monstrous, friend. And this plague is natural selection at work.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: We don't believe in free anything here in Edgewater. We're a Spacer's Choice company.

dialog.speaker: ConradSadik (Male)
dialog.utterance: No. Thank you. That's quite all right. I've seen enough body parts in my line of work.
